Taxonomy Landing Page Testing
A Narrative full of fun stuff about testing the taxonomy landing page

URL Format
The following endpoints are supported
taxonomy/taxon/NAMESPACE/ID/[TIMESTAMP]
Taxon landing page for viewing taxon ID in namespace NAMESPACE with optional TIMESTAMP.
See examples below.
taxonomy/about
placeholder
taxonomy/help
placeholder

NCBI
namespace: ncbi_taxonomy
Example for Escherichia coli:
https://ci.kbase.us#taxonomy/taxon/ncbi_taxonomy/562

GTDB
namespace: gtdb
Example for Escherichia coli:
https://ci.kbase.us#taxonomy/taxon/gtdb/GBGCA900481195.1

RDP
namespace: rdb_taxonomy
Example for Escherichia coli; PK3; X80731:
https://ci.kbase.us#taxonomy/taxon/rdp_taxonomy/S000000986

SILVA
namespace: silva_taxonomy
Example for Escherichia coli; PK3; X80731:
https://ci.kbase.us#taxonomy/taxon/silva_taxonomy/HG710171.1.771
NCBI namespace: ncbi_taxonomy Example for Escherichia coli: https://ci.kbase.us#taxonomy/taxon/ncbi_taxonomy
GTDB namespace: gtdb Example for Escherichia coli: https://ci.kbase.us#taxonomy/taxon/gtdb/GBGCA900481195.1
RDP namespace: rdb_taxonomy Example for Escherichia coli; PK3; X80731: https://ci.kbase.us#taxonomy/taxon
SILVA namespace: silva_taxonomy Example for Escherichia coli; PK3; X80731: https://ci.kbase.us#taxonomy

Ontology Landing Pages
Start at the root, and explore!
biological process - https://ci.kbase.us/#review/go_ontology/GO:0008150
biological process - https://ci.kbase.us/#review/go_ontology/GO:0008150

Taxonomy Landing Pages
The ubiquitous E. coli...
NCBI:
https://ci.kbase.us/#review/ncbi_taxonomy/562
GTDB:
https://ci.kbase.us#review/gtdb/GBGCA900481195.1

Relation engine landing page urls
A url to the relation engine landing page looks like:

https://ci.kbase.us#review/namespace/id[/ts]

where

review is the name of the relation engine landing page plugin endpoint; this is short for "relation engine view"
namespace is the collection to be accessed; e.g. ncbi_taxonomy, gtdb, go_ontology.
id is the identifier for the specific item to be viewed; the form of the id depends on the collection,e.g. 562 is E. coli in the ncbi taxonomy, GO:0008150 is the id for "biological process" in the go ontology.
ts is an optional timestamp associated with the specific instance of the item; items within a collection are stamped with an time range which defines when the item is valid; this is used to manage collection updates over time. If omitted, the most recent version of the item is selected

Taxonomy API
The kb sdk module taxonomy_re_api serves as the taxonomy api.
In order to test calls against it, you'll first need to get the url:
json
{
    "version": "1.1",
    "method": "ServiceWizard.get_service_status",
    "id": "9360468998301",
    "params": [{
        "module_name": "taxonomy_re_api",
        "version": "dev"
    }]
}

will give you something like:
json
{
    "version": "1.1",
    "result": [
        {
            "git_commit_hash": "5a120b167a19b7b5fb87a11c7c35f704a225c156",
            "status": "active",
            "version": "3.4.0",
            "hash": "5a120b167a19b7b5fb87a11c7c35f704a225c156",
            "release_tags": [
                "dev"
            ],
            "url": "https://ci.kbase.us:443/dynserv/5a120b167a19b7b5fb87a11c7c35f704a225c156.taxonomy-re-api",
            "module_name": "taxonomy_re_api",
            "health": "healthy",
            "up": 1
        }
    ],
    "id": "9360468998301"
}

Armed with the service url, it is handy to be able to find critters to explore:
The taxonomy_re_api.search_taxa method can be used with a free-form text search to find taxonomic entities:
json
{
    "params": [{
        "ns": "gtdb",
        "search_text": "coli"
    }],
    "method": "taxonomy_re_api.search_taxa",
    "version": "1.1",
    "id": "3658889363010196"
}

returns 
json
{
    "result": [
        {
            "stats": {
                "executionTime": 0.08076357841491699,
                "filtered": 0,
                "httpRequests": 0,
                "peakMemoryUsage": 1563242,
                "scannedFull": 0,
                "scannedIndex": 3147,
                "writesExecuted": 0,
                "writesIgnored": 0
            },
            "total_count": 3147,
            "results": [
                {
                    "_id": "gtdb_taxon/GB_GCA_900481195.1_r89",
                    "_key": "GB_GCA_900481195.1_r89",
                    "_rev": "_ZclM1Oa--e",

From here you can grab the id and make another call. The taxonomy api repo documents the api calls, which include:

get_taxon
gettaxonfromwsobj
getassociatedws_objects
get_lineage
get_children
get_siblings
search_species
search_taxa

json
{
    "params": [{
        "ns": "gtdb",
        "id": "GB_GCA_900481195.1"
    }],
    "method": "taxonomy_re_api.get_lineage",
    "version": "1.1",
    "id": "3658889363010196"
}
Taxonomy Landing Pages The ubiquitous E. coli...
identifier for the specific item to be viewed; the form of the id depends on the collection,e.g. 562 is E. coli
This narrative provide links to ontology and taxonomy landing pages.

Ontology Landing Page Examples
There is no object landing page support for re ontology yet, so we present some links to interesting ontology term landing pages:
Linked Features
This one should have linked features:
hatching behavior

Note: There were linked features appearing a few days ago, but not now.

Large Graph
need an example
Many children
need an example

Taxonomy Examples
Objects on the left don't have relations in place to their taxons, so the landing page shows an error message.
The examples from below use refdata objects because their relationships have been manually built.
Relationships are being built in real time, although given the mis-assignments at present it is a bit difficult to trace. The E. coli in the data panel to is actually linked from the "E. coli" taxon landing page you can get to from the genome landing page cited below. You can get back to this narrative from that link as well!

Genome Landing Page

E. coli refdata
This link leads to a Genome landing page which shows the lineage widget rewritten to use the Relation Engine to:
- get the taxon ref given the object ref
- get the taxon for the taxon ref
- get the lineage for the taxon ref
The lineage widget shows the existing lineage widget, which derives its data from the genome object itself (scientific name and lineage).
Clicking on the scientific name or any class in the lineage will open the associated taxonomy landing page.
The linked objects tab has 3 items.

Genome Landing Page

Pseudomonas aeruginosa refdata
This link leads to a Genome landing page which shows the lineage widget rewritten to use the Relation Engine to:
- get the taxon ref given the object ref
- get the taxon for the taxon ref
- get the lineage for the taxon ref
The lineage widget shows the existing lineage widget, which derives its data from the genome object itself (scientific name and lineage).
Clicking on the scientific name or any class in the lineage will open the associated taxonomy landing page.
The linked objects tab has 442 linked objects shows the scale better.
The E. coli in the data panel to is actually linked from the "E. coli" taxon landing page you can get
Genome Landing Page E. coli refdata This link leads to a Genome landing page which shows the lineage

Let's Annotate the kb|g.0 Genome (E Coli)

Microbial Metabolic Model Reconstruction and Analysis
Janaka's version

A key scientific objective of KBase’s Microbes team is to reconstruct and predict metabolic and transcriptional regulatory networks to facilitate the manipulation of microbial function (for example, to optimize biofuel products). This tutorial highlights the tools in KBase that support the reconstruction and analysis of genome-scale metabolic models from genome sequence data.

NOTE (to users): This tutorial is read-only. It shows the results of the steps. If you'd like to run the steps yourself--and maybe change some of the parameters or input your own data--you will need to make your own copy of it. Click the blue “Copy Narrative” button at the top right of the screen. This will copy the Narrative that you are currently viewing to your account, and you should see the new copy appear at the top of “My Narratives”. The copy is now yours–-you can open it, run it, edit it, and even share it with others. For more information, please see the Narrative User Guide.

The steps shown in this tutorial are:

1. Load a Genome into your Narrative
You can upload your own data to KBase to analyze it, but for demonstration purposes in this tutorial, we’ll start by choosing a data object—-a genome—-that's already in KBase and adding it to our Narrative.
To add the example genome, first click the Add Data (or red  “+”) button in the Data Panel on the left of your screen. (If you don’t see this button, make sure you have the Analyze tab selected.)

The Data Browser will slide out, with tabs that show several data sources. Select the Public tab and search for Escherichia coli K12.
Find the genome called "EscherichiacoliK12" and add it to your Narrative by hovering your cursor over it and clicking the Add button that appears at its left. (I will update this screenshot)

Exit the Data Browser by clicking either the Close button at the bottom right of the browser window or the arrow at the top of the Data Panel. (Note that you also can close the Data Browser by clicking anywhere in the main Narrative panel in the center.)
After a moment your Data Panel will update to show the dataset that you just added.

2. What's in your Genome object?
You can click on the ShewanellaoneidensisMR-1 genome object in your Data panel to see a genome viewer (see below).
If you click on the name of the genome at the top of the viewer (ShewanellaoneidensisMR-1), a Landing Page (also called Detail Page) for that genome will open in a new browser tab.
-- short explantion of each tab (from the genome man page/tutorial)

3. Reconstruction of Metabolic Model and Gapfill in Complete Media
KBase’s toolkit includes apps and methods for reconstruction, curation, reconciliation, and analysis of metabolic models. This section and the sections that follow explore some of that functionality.
Now that you’ve loaded a genome object into the narrative, you can build an initial draft metabolic model based on the gene annotations in your genome object.
Go to the APPS & METHODS panel at the left. (If you don't see it, make sure you're looking at the "Analyze" tab.)
In KBase, apps and methods are the same thing except that an app consists of more than one method. You can search for apps or methods using the search box at the top of the Apps & Methods Panel (click the magnifying glass), or just scroll until you find the one you want. Find the "Build Metabolic Model" method and click on its name (or icon) to add it as a new step in your Narrative.
Now you need to fill in the fields for the method. Choose the E. coli genome you loaded, and make up a name for the model that will be created. Then click the "Run" button at the bottom of the method cell to start building the model.
Explantion of each tab in the gapfilled metabolic model
Below is the output of the Gapfilled Metabolic Model method. You can look at the different tabs, etc. Need an explantion for each tab (man pages/tutorials may already have the text)

4. Run Flux Balance Analysis on Complete media
Once you have built a metabolic model, you can perform flux balance analysis (FBA) to calculate the flow of metabolites through your model. FBA results can be used to predict the growth rate of an organism under certain conditions or the production rates for particular metabolites of interest.
In order to perform FBA, you need to describe the media conditions that you want to investigate using your metabolic model. There are about 500 media conditions currently users have acces via the data pane under public tab. (Explantion of chosing media by flitering "Media" in the dropdown and adding
a media forumuation into the narrative.
Here we import a Phenotype Set...

Choose the E. coli genome you loaded, and make up a name for the model that will be created.
